External/Internal Connections Process Overview

This page provides a general overview of the connection process for IT assets. The specific requirements vary by asset type.

General Process Steps

  1. Asset Classification: Determine your asset type and review the appropriate guidelines
  2. Security Assessment: Complete the security questionnaire for your asset type
  3. Documentation: Prepare required technical documentation and justification
  4. Review & Approval: Submit for security and network team review
  5. Implementation: Configure approved connections with proper monitoring

Asset Type Specific Guidelines

  • End-User Device Onboarding - Laptops, workstations, mobile devices
  • Server Onboarding - Application servers, database servers, web servers
  • Network Equipment Onboarding - Switches, routers, firewalls, load balancers

All connections are logged and periodically reviewed for compliance. Contact IT Security for questions.
firewall-rules:
Firewall Rules & Network Security Overview

Understanding network security requirements across different asset types and network zones.

General Principles

  • Least Privilege: Only necessary connections are permitted
  • Defense in Depth: Multiple layers of security controls
  • Network Segmentation: Isolation between different security zones
  • Continuous Monitoring: All network traffic is logged and analyzed

Network Zones

  • DMZ: External-facing systems with internet access
  • Internal Network: Core business systems with restricted access
  • Secure Zone: High-security systems with additional controls
  • Management Zone: Administrative and monitoring systems

Asset-Specific Requirements

Review the appropriate asset type documentation for specific firewall and network requirements:

  • End-User Device Network Requirements
  • Server Network Requirements
  • Network Equipment Requirements

end-user-device:
End-User Device Onboarding Guide

Security requirements and guidelines for onboarding laptops, workstations, tablets, and mobile devices.

Security Assessment for End-User Devices

Physical Security

  • Device Storage: Devices should be stored in secure locations when not in use
  • Theft Prevention: Cable locks or secure storage for stationary devices
  • Asset Tagging: All devices must be properly tagged and inventoried

Communication Security

  • VPN Requirements: All remote connections must use approved VPN clients
  • Wireless Security: WPA3 encryption for wireless connections
  • Browser Security: Current browser versions with security extensions

Network Security

  • Network Access: Devices connect through managed network access points
  • Firewall Protection: Host-based firewall enabled and configured
  • Network Zone: Typically operates in End-User Network zone

Access Control

  • User Authentication: Multi-factor authentication required
  • Device Management: Enrolled in mobile device management (MDM) system
  • Data Access: Role-based access to business applications and data
server:
Server Onboarding Guide

Security requirements and guidelines for onboarding application servers, database servers, web servers, and other server infrastructure.

Security Assessment for Servers

Physical Security

  • Data Center Location: Servers must be located in approved, secure data centers
  • Physical Access: Controlled access with logging and monitoring
  • Environmental Controls: Proper cooling, power, and fire suppression

Communication Security

  • Encryption in Transit: TLS 1.2+ for all client-server communications
  • API Security: OAuth 2.0 or certificate-based authentication for APIs
  • Inter-Server Communication: Encrypted channels between server components

Network Security

  • Network Segmentation: Servers isolated in appropriate network zones
  • Firewall Rules: Restrictive rules allowing only necessary traffic
  • Load Balancer Integration: Traffic routed through approved load balancers
  • Network Zone: Internal, DMZ, or Secure zone based on function

Access Control

  • Administrative Access: Privileged access management with session recording
  • Service Accounts: Dedicated service accounts with minimal privileges
  • Certificate Management: Automated certificate lifecycle management
  • Audit Logging: Comprehensive logging of all access and activities
network-equipment:
Network Equipment Onboarding Guide

Security requirements and guidelines for onboarding switches, routers, firewalls, load balancers, and other network infrastructure.

Security Assessment for Network Equipment

Physical Security

  • Secure Installation: Equipment installed in locked cabinets or secure rooms
  • Console Access: Physical console ports secured and monitored
  • Cable Management: Network cables properly secured and labeled

Communication Security

  • Management Protocols: SSH, HTTPS, or SNMPv3 for device management
  • Routing Security: Secure routing protocols with authentication
  • Control Plane Protection: Rate limiting and access controls

Network Security

  • Network Segmentation: VLANs and routing policies for traffic separation
  • Access Control Lists: Granular traffic filtering and control
  • DDoS Protection: Traffic analysis and mitigation capabilities
  • Network Zone: Management zone with dedicated management network

Access Control

  • Administrative Access: Role-based access with strong authentication
  • TACACS+ Integration: Centralized authentication and authorization
  • Configuration Management: Automated configuration deployment and backup
  • Monitoring Integration: SNMP monitoring with security event correlation
